resources.string: The Brain Injury Strategies App is intended to provide ideas for supporting an individual who is returning to learning.

string-array.name: strategies
string-array.item: -A concussion is a type of traumatic brain injury
-It takes a child/adolescent an average of 7 to 21 days to recover fully from a concussion
-Because of risk of further brain damage, the most important and most immediate action following a concussion is to reduce PHYSICAL, BEHAVIORAL and MENTAL activity

string.name: fatigueinfo
string.item: The Student may:\n \t-Tire Quickly (physically and/or mentally)\n \t-Have reduced tolerance and ability to cope

string.name: sensoryinfo
string.item:
The Student may have:
 	* Light Sensitivity:
 		 -Double vision or blurry vision
 		 -Difficulty reading and copying and/or paying attention
		 to visual tasks.
 	* Noise Sensitivity:
 		-Difficulty coping with noise level in variety of school
		 settings 
 		 (hallways, lunchroom, music classes, 
		 shop classes, physical education).
 	* Motor symptoms
 		 - Dizziness/lightheadedness, which can make standing
		 or walking in crowds challenging
 		- Difficulties with fine motor tasks
		 (writing, using scissors, drawing)

string.name: attentioninfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Appear not to listen
 	-Miss details
 	-Forget what people have said
 	-Have difficulties concentrating
 	-Be unable to cope with more than one thing at a time
 	-Be easily distracted
 	-Change the subject often
 	-Get bored easily

string.name: selfmonitoringinfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Show poor adherence to rules
 	-Not realize they have made errors
 	-'Hog' conversations ; be verbose and keep talking
 	 when others are no longer interested
 	-Have lower tolerance for frustating situations

string.name: receptiveinfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have difficulty understanding
 	-Non verbal communication /body language ; 
 	-take statements literally

string.name: expressiveinfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have difficulty initiating
 		and maintaining conversation (participation)

string.name: speedinfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Take Longer to complete tasks
 	-Take longer to answer questions
 	-Be unable to keep track of lengthy conversations

string.name: planninginfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have difficulty preparing for a task
 	-Be unable to work out the steps involved in a task
 	-Have problem with organizing their own thoughts
 	 and explaining things to others

string.name: memoryinfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have difficulty learning new things
 	-Be forgetful 
 	-Lose things
 	- Have difficulty recalling what they've learned

string.name: reasoninginfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have rigid and concrete thinking style;
 	 take statements literally
 	-Be resistant to change
 	-Have a simplistic understanding of emotions
 	-show poor judgement and poor decision making skills

string.name: problemsolvinginfo
string.item:
The Student may:
 	-Have difficulty working out solutions to the problem
 	-Be unable to generate new ideas
 	-have disordered approach to problem solving

string-array.name: fatiguestrategies
string-array.item: Consider Focussing on core/priority subjects (Math, Science, History and English)
Consider shortening the school day
Encourage person to take breaks

string-array.name: fatiguesubstrategies00
string-array.item: Schedule More demanding or essential tasks when student is at his/her best
Shorten, reduce or break down assignments into smaller manageable chunks that the student can complete without getting frustrated or having symptoms worsen
Assign a note taker
Allow student to record lectures
Provide lecture notes/Powerpoint slides or teacher tapes lectures/discussions for student to replay later

string-array.name: fatiguesubstrategies01
string-array.item: have student arrive at school later or leave earlier, depending on when the student is best able to handle academic work

string-array.name: fatiguesubstrategies02
string-array.item: Break time means resting the brain and the body. Breaks can be at regular intervals or as needed.
Breaks may be needed during classes, tests and/or homework assignments
Predetermined where a student can rest with supervision (clinic, library, guidance counselor\'s office, or school\'s main office).

string-array.name: sensorystrategies
string-array.item: Restrict visual stimuli
Address physical issues
Reduce noise

string-array.name: sensorysub0
string-array.item: Allow student to wear sunglasses or hat in school
Sit away from bright sunlight, dim lights or close the blinds
Warn student if lights will be turned on/off during class
Reduce exposure or brightness on screens (computers, tablets, Smart boards)
Consider using audio books

string-array.name: sensorysub1
string-array.item: Allow student to leave class early to transition to next class before the halls are crowded
Encourage student to walk with a peer
Allow student to use the elevator, if available
Limit or avoid gym, recess, athletics
Consider reducing paper / pencil tasks or allow extra time for tasks requiring fine motor skills
Allow student to record or type assignments

string-array.name: sensorysub2
string-array.item: Allow student to have lunch in a quiet area with a classmate
Encourage student to sit away from talkative peers, open windows or school intercoms.
Limit or avoid band, choir, physical education or shop class
Allow students to avoid loud events (pep rallies, athletic events, dances, assemblies)
Allow student to leave class early to transition to next class before the halls are crowded
Consider the use of earplugs
Alert student when there is going to be a tornado or fire drill

string-array.name: selfstrategies
string-array.item: Encourage turn taking in conversations
Use a variety of techniques to remember needed behaviors.
Provide feedback promptly and in a respectful manner when errors occur
Teach the student to repeat or re-explain directions in his/her own words to increase understanding
Create and use signals to let him/her know when he/she is talking too much
Teach student how to use class and individual schedules
Teaching Coping Strategies

string-array.name: selfsub0
string-array.item: Help plan social times with friends
Foster friendships with positive role models

string-array.name: selfsub1
string-array.item: Use memory tricks such as mnemonics, phrases or acronyms\n (SLANT- Sit up, Lean Forward, Ask Questions, Nod head, Track Teacher)
Rehearse new routines and procedures
Create a predetermined signal for student to use \n when ready to answer a question or present in front of the class
Encourage the use of lists, schedules, assignment sheet or planner

string-array.name: selfsub2
string-array.item: Evaluate each step for effectiveness and \n discuss what went well and what needs to be done differently.

string-array.name: selfsub3
string-array.item: Guide student to visualize then verbalize each step

string-array.name: selfsub4
string-array.item: Help each student decide on individual signal

string-array.name: selfsub5
string-array.item: May be pictures or written

string-array.name: selfsub6
string-array.item: Use Social stories to demonstrate how to cope with situations
Provide structured social skills groups
Teach relaxation (deep breathing)

string-array.name: attentionstrategies
string-array.item: Use short and specific instructions on assignments
Remove/reduce unnecessary distractions in the classroom
Make use of color coding and underlining to focus \n attention on important points
Use visual/verbal cues to redirect student\â€™s attention
Teach self-monitoring techniques

string-array.name: attentionsub0
string-array.item: Provide \'windows\' cut from cardboard to expose only one segment at a time
Block extraneous information on page

string-array.name: attentionsub1
string-array.item: Decrease multiple assignments if due simultaneously
Consider lessening or removing environmental distractions \n such as lighting or noise
Allow the student to wear sunglasses if light sensitive
Allow student to wear earplugs or headphones if noise sensitive

string-array.name: attentionsub2
string-array.item: Highlight number of problems or directions to direct student to \n important information

string-array.name: attentionsub3
string-array.item: Shorten instructions/activities so they can be completed
Write down instructions accurately and in a way that \n can be easily understood later

string-array.name: attentionsub4
string-array.item: Set student goals for how much of a task they can complete \n in an allotted time
Use techniques such as SLANT \n (sit up, lean forward, ask questions, nod your head, track the teacher) to \n help them remember the needed behaviors

string-array.name: receptivestrategies
string-array.item: Monitor your language during instruction
Allow frequent opportunities for review of content material
Provide alternate ways to demonstrate mastery of content
Provide more time for a student to process information
Use visual cues with explicit language

string-array.name: receptivesub0
string-array.item: Speak clearly at a slower pace
Use direct and explicit language
Repeat important statements // directions
Avoid colloquialisms // figurative language

string-array.name: receptivesub1
string-array.item: State key points prior to and at the end of lessons
Ask review questions (of entire class) at regular intervals
Repeat important concepts out loud
Use a variety of instructional strategies to teach a siongle concept
Model (or have a peer model) activities or steps
Allow student to record lessons with audio device

string-array.name: receptivesub2
string-array.item: Allow more time when taking tests, completing assignments.
Allow students to answer tests orally rather than written
Allow test or activity to be \"open book\" or \"take home\"
Allow students to work with a partner on a project
Provide a list of acceptable forms of demonstrating understanding \n (book report, video report, etc.)

string-array.name: receptivesub3
string-array.item: Provide extra pause time when asking student a question or opening \n up discussions (\"Let\'s think about that for a minute. \")
Allow more time to complete assignments and tests

string-array.name: receptivesub4
string-array.item: Use graphic organizer for lessons // units of study
Always provide text or graphic pf important content, assignments, \n and directions (write // post on white board, SmartBoard, bulletin board, etc.)
Provide yout lesson notes to student for reference and review
During oral discussion, write talking points on chart paper and\n post in classroom
Use technology such as an ipad, to depicit a social story, \n directions or steps to a process, graphically or through text.
Post mnemonic strategies when used to support lesson

string-array.name: speedstrategies
string-array.item: Consider additional wait time for students \n responding to questions
Encourage the use of lecture aids
Present onle one item at a time
Reduce the amount of work given in the class \n and for homework
Decide what conepts are essential for learning
Encourage the use of organizational aids

string-array.name: speedsub0
string-array.item: Allow students to answer for themselves
Ask one question at a time

string-array.name: speedsub1
string-array.item: Reduce devices, student note buddy, or copies of teacher\'s notes
Allow student to concentrate on lecture instead of writing and\n listening at the same time

string-array.name: speedsub2
string-array.item: Avoid cognitive overload.

string-array.name: speedsub3
string-array.item: Extend time to give brain longer to process information
Break each lesson into mangeable sections
Give student Instructor\'s notes or powerpoint
Highlight important words and symbols
Allow student to have flash cards or graphic organizers for activities
Give homework only when student is fully back to learning

string-array.name: speedsub4
string-array.item: Wait to do extensions until student has fully returned to learn
Explore some concepts at a later date
Avoid multi-step concepts as well as deductive reasoning
Allow extra time for necessary assignments and dismiss some \n assignments wntirely if possible

string-array.name: speedsub5
string-array.item: Venn Diagrams, charts, flash cards with information on conditional \n statements
Graphic organizers
Visual strategies
Checklists
Planners

string-array.name: reasoningstrategies
string-array.item: Provide real life examples when offerring explanations
Avoid using emotional undertones
Explain changes in routine in advance, giving reasons
Prioritize work

string-array.name: reasoningsub0
string-array.item: Expect student to participate in group discussion about real-life\n situations: explore pros and cons and alternatives
Connect information to past experiences to make task more\n meaningful for the student

string-array.name: reasoningsub1
string-array.item: Consider consistent, neutral feedback
Provide verbal remonders of expected behavior
Help the student identify signs from the environment \n to use as a model for brhavior

string-array.name: reasoningsub2
string-array.item: Discuss change with student and check for understanding
Plan alternative solutions for change

string-array.name: reasoningsub3
string-array.item: Help student to decide what to do first
Highlight most important points
Review at least two different options and let student select one
Break tasks into smaller and shorter segments

string-array.name: memorystrategies
string-array.item: Provide strategies keeping track of belongings
Encourage use of memory aids
Provide information and opportunities for repetition

string-array.name: memorysub0
string-array.item: Place items in certain sections of backpack or book bag
Use color coding for folders \/ files for class assignments
Designate specific location for storing personal items

string-array.name: memorysub1
string-array.item: Consider using any of the following: Schedules, assignment sheets,\n calendars, checklists, journals, times tables, word banks, or flash cards
Use visuals to present copntent: Graphic organizers, diagrams, flow\n charts, or outline.
Encourage student to use self-questioning, \"wh\" questions \n (who,what,when, where, why, how)

string-array.name: memorysub2
string-array.item: Provide an outline or overview of material to be covered in class
Provide class notes to the student or assign a note taker
Provide lecture notes/PowerPoint slides
Teacher tapes lectures/discussions for student to replay later \n or allow student to record lectures
Repeat information (Frequent review) to reinforce learning
Provide multiple opportunities for practice in different formats.
Present information in several formats (Verbal, written, visuals, modelling)

string-array.item: Encourage student to take time to think\n before they speak
Use color coding
Provide strategies to help students prepare for \n a task or complete a task

string-array.item: Provide extra time for strudent to answer
Give student the questions ahead of time

string-array.name: planningsub1

Highlight important steps or information

string-array.name: planningsub2
string-array.item: Have student repeat the directions or provide written directions

Use visuals (diagrams, flow charts, outlines, pictures)
Use assignment sheets/books and calendars to track assignments

string-array.name: problemstrategies
string-array.item: Teach how to develop a step by step guide for problem solving
Teach material in small chunks
Identify achievable outcomes for the task, ensure there is a purpose
Consider giving specific tasks
Consider breaking the task into smaller components

string-array.name: problemsub0
string-array.item: Identify the problem
Consider relevant information
List and evaluate possible solutions
Create a plan of action
Evaluate the plan of action

string-array.name: problemsub1
string-array.item: Allow student to get a great deal of practice with one step at a time
Avoid cognitive overload with smaller pieces of information

string-array.name: problemsub2
string-array.item: Explain time management and prioritizing
Teach how to develop short and long term goals

string-array.name: problemsub3
string-array.item: Provide predetermined tasks because open-ended tasks may be \n overwhelming for the student

string-array.name: problemsub4
string-array.item: Provide step by step visual directions and instructions
Start with when project is due and work backwards
Determine when each step needs to be completed

string-array.name: expressivestrategies
string-array.item: Minimize the stress of speaking in class
Use open-ended questions and statements
Review steps for communication situations

string-array.name: expressivesub0
string-array.item: Pair students in the class for discussion activities
Provide alternate forms of presentation of projects \n (i.e, student videotaping of oral sections, poster presentation, \n graphic organizers etc.)
Help student review the topic(s) for the following day so the\n student can prepare at least one statement or response\n in order to contribute during the next day\'s discussion.

string-array.name: expressivesub1
string-array.item: Prompt discussion with reflective questions such as \n \" What do you think about that \" and \" Tell me about . . . \"
As appropriate, encourage reflective thinking when reviewing content

string-array.name: expressivesub2
string-array.item: Help STudent break communication situations into small, \n discrete parts and discuss how to be successful within each part
Use video modelling as a means of reviewing and \n discussing a communication situation
Role-play with the student appropriate language to \n use in different situations
